participants.participant: Theodore M. Helms, Executive Manager, Investor Relations
Almir Guilherme Barbassa, Chief Financial Officer and Investor Relations Director

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Petrobras conference call to discuss the fourth quarter 2010 results. At this time, all lines are in a listen-only mode. Later, there will be a question and answer session, and instructions will be given at that time.

Today, with us, we have Mr. Almir Guilherme Barbassa, Petrobras CFO and Investor Relations Officer, and his staff. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Theodore Helms, Investor Relations Executive Manager of Petrobras, who has some additional comments.
Please go ahead, Mr. Theodore.

Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our conference call to discuss fourth quarter and 2010 results. We have a simultaneous webcast on the Internet that could be accessed at the site www.petrobras.com.br/ri/english.

Before proceeding, I'd like to draw your attention to Slide 2. We may make forward-looking statements which are identified by use of the words "will," expect," and similar that are based on the beliefs and assumptions of Petrobras' management and on information currently available to the company.

Finally, let me mention that this conference call will discuss Petrobras' results prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards, IFRS, and Brazilian legislation. At this moment, we are unable to discuss any issues related to U.S. GAAP results.

The conference call will be conducted by our CFO, Mr. Almir Guilherme Barbassa. He will comment on the company's operating and financial highlights, and the main events during this quarter, and he will be available to answer any questions you may have.
Almir, please begin.
Thank you for joining our conference call to discuss fourth quarter and full-year results.

2010 was a year of milestones, as we execute our long-term business plan. We completed the largest capitalization ever by acquiring the rights to produce an additional 5 billion barrels of oil. We installed six new production systems, including the first pilot system in the Lula fields. In December, we set daily and monthly production records. And for the first time, annual and daily production in Brazil exceeded 2 million barrels per day. We are more than halfway through the complete modernization of our existing refining products and are now constructing two new refineries. We have all but completed our natural gas infrastructure, and we anchored the first floating production system in Gulf of Mexico.

Next, please. Each of our business segments contributed positively to our 2010 financial results. Results for the year were strongly blessed by the rising oil production and international oil prices, strong domestic demand, and the strengthening real, and stable product price in Brazil. The balance and integration between our upstream and downstream operations and our pricing policy that kept price stable in Brazil while it increased internationally resulted in upstream Brazilian operation meeting our end goals. Gas and Energy grew on the strength of increasing demand and infrastructure, while international operation benefited from a higher price environment.

The Consumer Price Index in Brazil was 5.91% in 2010, causing an increase in costs throughout our operations. Volumes transported and sold grew by 11%, leading to higher costs even as their unit costs were stable. For the year, our annual operating income was up 4%, while our net income increased by 17%.

Next. For 2010, oil and gas production was 2.004 million barrels per day, up 2% for the year. We had set a target of 2.1 million barrels of oil in Brazil per day but did not reach that target. The reasons for the shortfall were unplanned stoppage requests by the Brazilian National Petroleum Agency, ANP; the need to reduce production in Marlim Leste field to increase the pressure of reservoir; and delays in the start of production systems such as Guará and Tiro‐Sídon. It is worth highlighting the growth in natural gas production of 5% in 2010. We expect to grow even more this year as we complete the important connections to our gas network in This will allow us to incorporate non-associated gas production from , including gas from the Pre-salt. Our international production increased 2%, primarily from Nigeria. This year, Cascade and Chinook in the Gulf of Mexico will start up and contribute to results.

Next. For 2011, we have set a target of 2.1 million barrels of oil per day in Brazil. We are confident that we can achieve this target based on December production of 2.1 million barrels per day. And assuming an average decline of 10%, we must replace 210,000 barrels per day of decline. As you can see from the slide, we expect to meet this target from a number of changes.

in Campos Basin will contribute 120,000 barrels per day. We have P-57 installed last year, and the installation of P-56 in July next will add another 85,000 barrels per day. We have half of the Lula pilot and the Pre-salt production in the current stage are expected to contribute 60,000 barrels per day. The addition of these 265,000 barrels per day should compensate for the decline, as well as for having to stoppage and any other contingency that may occur.

It is worth highlighting the discoveries we have been making in the Carbonate reservoir in the concession in the Campos Pre-salt. In the last two years, we have discovered our first 2 billion barrels of recoverable oil in the concession in the Campos Basin in Carbonate reservoir located above and below .

We are beginning to tie back these reservoirs to existing production systems. The latest example is Tracaja, where we just announced in which one well is producing 23,000 barrels per day. In December we announced Carimbe, with initial capacity of 24,000 barrels per day. We have two additional wells planned for Carbonate in Barracuda and Marlim for later this year.

Next, please. In the Pre-salts, we continue to progress, with results meeting or exceeding our expectations. In this slide, you can see the accomplishment of trends there. Some of our accomplishments include acquisition of the rights to produce an additional 5 billion barrels of oil in the Santos Pre-salt; the start-up of Lula pilots; the start-up of Guará extended well tests; and eight additional wells drilling.

For 2011, we expect a number of key results: 12 rigs working the area by the end of the year; drilling of another 20 wells, double what we have drilled so far. will be completions. Two of the wells will be drilled in areas we acquired rights last year, producing 5 million barrels of oil. For production, we have the Lula pilot ramping up whilst two platform producing three extended well tests during the year.

Next. Our production continues to be supported by the incorporation of proven reserves. This year we replaced 240% of our production, the 18th consecutive year we have replaced more than 100% of Brazilian production. On the SPE basis, we now have a reserve production life of 18 years. As you can, see our greatest success has been finding oil in deep and ultra-deep waters, including the Pre-salts. 2010 was the first year we began booking Santos Pre-salt reserves, which contributes 1.07 billion barrels to our proved reserves. Onshore and shallow water proved reserves have remained stable, even as their share declines. International reserves, particularly those in Latin America, have declined.

To speak a little bit on rigs. During the last several years, the lack of drilling rigs has been the single greatest limitation to increase our production. We addressed this problem by incentivizing the construction of new rigs with long-term contracts signed in 2005 and 2008. Only now are these rigs arriving in Brazil.

The slide shows the increase of the contracted fleet of drilling rigs. We have increased our fleet capable of drilling water deeper than 2,000 meters from three in 2007, when we discovered the Pre-salt, to 15 in 2010, with another 19 to be delivered through 2012. Solving our needs of this critical resource is an important milestone on our path to double carbon production by 2020.

For our long-term needs, we are taking steps to develop a rig industry in Brazil. We have concluded the first phase of the structured award in construction of seven drilling rigs to Estaleiro Atlântico Sul. The $662 million cost of each rig, when translated into equivalent days rate, is competitive with existing market rates. The financing of these rigs is already well under way, with commitment from third-party equity and debt sources. Petrobras intends to participate initially with 10% of the assets of the new company that is going to own these new rigs. Still to be concluded are the bid packets in which operators are bidding for long-term contract to be supplied by . Discussions with potential operators are now ongoing.

Next. We already have success with developing the capacity to build FPSOs in Brazil. Compared with literally no such capacity 10 years ago, Brazil now has a number of new shipyards and a supplier network that are internationally competitive and directly adjacent to our operations. The shipyards have the additional value to supporting our ongoing operations, particularly with respect to maintenance and optimized activities. Today we have seven units under construction in Brazil at five different shipyards. There are another 13 shipyards under construction in Brazil. In addition to the seven units under construction, we have begun construction of eight FPSOs for the Pre-salt.

We continue to make gains in increasing the capacity of local suppliers to meet the demand of the Brazilian oil industry. Since 2003, local content has increased from 57% to 74% even as total investment spending has increased more than $20 billion.

2010 was a breakout year for natural gas and power, as growing industrial and commercial demand combined with peak thermoelectrical generation. As you can see, overall demand for natural gas was up 38% while thermoelectric generation tripled. But averages do not tell the whole story, as power demand appeared mainly during the dry season from . During that time, thermoelectric generation was as high as 6.5 gigawatts, with natural gas consumption reaching 86 million cubic meters per day. This clearly demonstrates that our gas and power infrastructure has now been built with the capacity and flexibility to respond to peak demand.

By the first quarter of 2011, we will have essentially completed our gas infrastructure. The last remaining project will connect natural gas production from Mexilhão, Uruguá, Tambaú, and Lula pilots to our grid. When completed, we will be able to deliver another 17 million cubic meters of domestically produced natural gas to the market. In doing so we will substitute domestic gas for natural gas we currently import. vertically integrated business, with an average realization price to the distributor of nearly $7 per million Btu in 2010, natural gas will become a growing component of Petrobras' operating income.

Next. During 2010, we saw tangible results from our investments in downstream. With the expansion of REPLAN, we will be able to increase throughput by 63,000 barrels per day. And increasing outputs of jet fuel. The REVAP coker modernization will substantially increase production of low-sulfur diesel and reduce our output of fuel oil. The REFAP acquisition will enable us to double our throughput of domestic oil at the refinery.

During 2010, the percentage of domestic oil as throughput increased from 79 in 2009 to 82% in 2010. There's no major turnaround planned for 2011. Utilization rates and domestic throughput are expected to remain near these levels throughout the year, helping to reduce costs and expand margins.

Turning to our financial results, we begin with volumes and price, which are the key determinants of our results. For the full year, Brent increased by $18 per barrel or 29% over 2009, while the value of our own crude increased by $20 per barrel, or 38% during the year. Due to our pricing policy of minimizing the volatility of international markets, the increase in international price was not fully reflected in domestic price. During 2010, the margin between U.S. and Brazilian price declined from average of $13.40 per barrel in 2009 to $4.50 per barrel in 2010, which had the effect of reducing refining margin but stabilizing our consolidated cash flow.

During the fourth quarter, our average realization price for product was relatively flat, which reduced the gap between Gulf Coast price and the Brazilian realization price. Oil price moved up faster at the end of the fourth quarter combined with our record production. However, this positive effect was absorbed by the revenue associated with our short-term adjustment oil products exports, and international sales. In December, Gulf Coast prices slightly exceeded the prices in Brazil, the first time since November 2008 that this has occurred. We continue to monitor price closely and remain committed to international price in the long term.

Next. Accelerating Brazilian GDP growth is reflected in higher product sales. For the full year, product sales were up 11%, reflecting the exceptional growth of the Brazilian economy. Of note is growth of jet fuel, up 19% year-over-year, as growing income and the stronger real stimulated air travel. Gasoline consumption increased 17% year-over-year as growing income, combined with higher sugar price, increased ethanol price, reducing its competitiveness. Natural gas consumption grew by 33%, reflecting growing industrial demand, but more importantly a greater reliance on gas-fired thermoelectric power for Brazil power grid.
From the third quarter to the fourth quarter, total product sales were up 1%, due to sales largely offsetting higher gasoline and jet fuel sales.

Lifting costs. Expressed in reais, lifting costs before government take declined by 6% in the fourth quarter. Lifting costs in the third quarter had been affected by the charges related to the annual collective bargaining agreement, bonus, and non-programmed stoppages. For the full year, lifting costs in reais were up 2%, while the U.S. dollars increase was 14%. The increase in dollars for lifting cost is largely attributable to the value of the real, valuation of the real, which rose by 12%.

For the year, total lifting costs were up 30% in U.S. dollars and 10% in reais, largely due to increased production tax related to the higher international reference price for oil. The growth in domestic consumption was met largely by imports of products. Over time, as production and refinery capacity in Brazil increases, we will be able to capture the margin that is being lost in imports.

Turning to financial results, revenue for the full year of 2010 were higher largely because of growing sales volume in Brazil. Our pricing policy means that revenue did not keep pace with the higher costs associated with the import of oil and products, higher production tax due to the higher international reference price, and the net inflation. Cost of goods sold also increased due to growing particularly LNG to meet higher demand. Sales expense increased largely because of cost associated with higher volumes. Virtually all the increase related -which related to LNG regas terminal, and other logistics cost to meet growing domestic demand. The increase in general and administration costs of 8% is due to cost of inflation, which largely contributed to increasing personnel cost, which grew slightly above inflation rate. Our work force grew by 3% last year, very reasonable considering all we have accomplished.

Next. Net financial results including tax and minority interests contributed to the 17% increase in the net income in 2010. There were several reasons for the increase. The real expansion of 25% versus the dollar in 2009, but only 4% in 2010. Since Petrobras has a net liability position dollar, the benefit was less than in 2009. Offsetting these benefits, Petrobras had a number of intercompany loans denominated in dollars in 2009. These were registered as U.S. dollar assets in Brazil. When the dollar weakens versus the real, our expense improves. Since then these loans were substantially reduced, thereby limiting the expense from the devaluation of the dollar.

Higher balance of interest-bearing government securities added to income. The net effect of these movements caused an increase in the net financial results of R$2.4 billion since '09. Minority interest expense declined due to the reduction in income from a subsidiary with minority interest, primarily because of lower earnings from the net financial results in 2010.

Comparing third quarter to fourth quarter, net revenues were down slightly due to flat prices and a 1% volume increase. Revenues would have been higher except for revenue from cargos of crudes and product export late in the quarter not yet recognized. The higher cost of goods sold was a result of high international price for imported oil and oil products and natural gas. Higher costs were partially offset by lower expenses, particularly those associated with the collective bargaining agreement. Inventory average benefited fourth quarter results by lowering cost of goods sold by R$543 million. at a lower cost. The lower revenue, combined with higher cost of goods sold, reduced gross income by 4% over the third quarter.
Expense declined by 11%, largely as a result of a few extraordinary items, particularly those relating to the collective bargaining agreement, the termination of the Barracuda project finance and...

Next, please. Turning to CapEx, capital spending totaled R$76 billion during 2010, an increase of 8% from the prior year. Capital expenditure by Brazilian exploration production increased by 5%, largely related to increased spending in the Pre-salt. Downstream spending grew by 70%, as an investment for upgrades, regulatory spending, and logistics is peaking while spending on the Abreu e Lima refinery ramps up.
Gas and Energy spending declined as the gas infrastructure reached completion. Our International segment also was reduced, as capitalized spending remained focus on integrated operations in Brazil.

Next. For 2011, our budget, as set forth in our annual business plan is R$93.7 billion. This amounts to 5.8% above what was approved last year. This budget is similar to the level of investment forecasted for 2011 in the 2010-2014 business plan, with a small increase to reflect initial exploration of the transfer of rights acreage. The allocation of investments for 2011 follows the pattern of 2010, with increased spending in Brazilian upstream and downstream, and continued reduction in gas and energy, with stable spending internationally. We are now planning to give a full update of our business plan for 2011-2015 in the second quarter of this year.

Next. The capital raised in 2010 has given us a very comfortable position with respect to liquidity and leverage. We ended the year with net debt to net capital of 17% and net debt to EBITDA of 1 time. These are well below the limits we have established for the company. We ended the year with cash and equivalents including government securities, maturity above 90 days, of R$55 billion. Our bonds continue to be well received by the debt capital markets, where we issued $6 billion of 5-, 10-, and 30-years maturity in January. For the remainder of the year, we will have our international as well as .
With that overview, we will now be happy to answer any questions. Thank you.

Our next question comes from Paul Cheng from Barclays Capital. Please go ahead.

Hi, guys. Two questions. One, the dividend and the interest on capital for 2010 has gone to about 35%. I think historically you guys are roughly about in the 30%. Is that the new percentage guideline that we should use going forward? The second question is on the Cap – yeah?

Yes. Not exactly. What happened is that according to the law and the regulation in Brazil, the traditional shares, they have the right to receive at least 25% of the net income or 5% of the value of the financial share in the capital of the company. And in this year, in the case of 2010, 5% were greater than the 25%, so we had to pay the minimum 5% of the value of the shares as a dividend, and not to pay a different value to the voting shares, we made the same for all of them. In this way, we had to pay a dividend of 35%. But assume that this reason will not happen again. We shall go back to the 25%.

So the growth in real in the CapEx from R$89 billion to R$93 billion, this is the comparison you have to do; that is about 5%. This is always a very important point for us in managing production and the decline rate, and the depletion is one of the most important indicators of the opportunities, the remaining opportunities, to improve recovery and to keep the production as flat as possible, optimizing the use of the existing infrastructure and production units. Then the behavior of these big giant fields, they do not behave as a linear decline, like a 10% or 8%. In general, in the very beginning of the production, they experience a higher decline. And as more mature or after a few years in a very low decline rate, which means that it tends to be much more hyperbolic than linear or even exponential.

But in the case of these fields, there is always an opportunity to drill more wells and to keep exploring new opportunities close to the field in order to keep them producing as flat as possible, with the lowest decline rate as possible. That's what we are doing. With the combination of – we call we call the exploration side of it also combined with in-field drilling and the management of water injection.

This is number of factors to manage the depletion and the decline rate. In some fields, we can experience rates bigger than 10% in the beginning. I'm assuming that's what you could see in the data from ANP, but we are not concerned with this bigger number for these fields, because it's part of the management to manage. Sometimes we don't have spare capacity to reduce these decline rates, but sometimes it is because of the water production, then the liquids in the platform can be the same with some decline in oil and replace it by water.
